captions.text:
Good morning John. Now you may have heard
that young women are insecure. And also young

men. And also old men and old women and kite
surfers and musicians and CEOs and you and

me and everyone deals with insecurity. But
there are a lot of young women here on YouTube

and also I think that they've been told
their entire lives to base their self-worth

on whether or not they are admired by men.
So there's an entire genre of video on YouTube

dedicated to the idea of telling women what
men like to see in them. So I figured, since

those videos do very well, I should hop on
the bandwagon myself and tell you what boys
look for in girls.

In Ethiopia's Karo tribe, women scar their
bellies as a form of sacred ceremonial tattoo

that is found to be very sexy. In the Kayan
tribe of Thailand, women use brass rings to

compress their chest and clavicle so that
their neck appears very long. The Mursi of

Ethiopia insert ceremonial plaques into their
lips to attract a man. In Japan, women have

their teeth cosmetically unstraightened because
crowded teeth is seen as endearing, while

a tribe in Indonesia thinks the height of
sexiness is pointy teeth, so they sharpen

their teeth with files. In 19th century Europe,
women wore garments that squeezed their waists

to tiny, tiny shapes while in Mauritania,
women send their daughters off to fat camps

to eat ten thousand calories a day because
there, stretch marks are seen as the height

of sexiness. Meanwhile in America, women appear
beautiful by painting their faces and shaving

their bodies. Likewise, different cultures
have different standards of beauty for men.

In England, they wear really tight pants for
example. And I wish I could pull those pants
off; I can't.

I have a point... several. But my main point
is that there is very little objectivity when

it comes to human mate selection. We're
crazy, we don't make any sense. And thus,

since whether or not someone wants to date
you is apparently based on complete randomness,

it's kind of a super terrible thing to base
your self-worth on. And this is regardless

of your gender, by the way. But I do think
that it's more of a problem for women. I

saw a post on Tumblr the other day; it was
wonderful. It said 'How do boys look so

hot and they never have to wear makeup?'
It was one on those moments where suddenly

you notice the water you've been swimming
in your whole life, right? Like we're always

surrounded by culture; we never notice it's
there; that's how culture works. But in

that moment, you're like 'Yeah! How come
boys don't have to wear makeup to look hot

and girls do?' 'Cause boys without makeup
don't look better than girls without makeup,

but in our culture they do, and I think that's
because we're pretty adamant about the fact

that women's value is based, not entirely
but significantly, on their beauty and that

a lot of their purpose is to be attractive
to men, which is messed up.

Of course, there's nothing wrong with wanting
to express yourself through your physical

appearance; everybody does that to some extent.
Makeup and fashion are supercool ways to express

yourself. We should express ourselves in all
of the ways that we can find to express ourselves

in - with our words and our actions and our
ideas and our clothes and our fingernails

and our haircuts. Don't let anybody rag
on you for expressing yourself however you

want to do it. And there's nothing wrong
with wanting to be appreciated for how you

look. I want to be appreciated for how I look,
but there is so much more to you that that.

There's so much more to life than that.
Girls are not the photons that hit the corneas

of boys. Regardless of your gender, regardless
of their gender, you do not exist to please

someone else. You exist for your own sake.
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

(Music)
Did you ever wanna go

To back where we were before
Smell that pot smoke wafting out

From under your dad's door
And the steak knives by the bedside
Jokes cracked in the blacklight

title: What Boys Look For in Girls

Pffttt... I hate make-up. All I own is ChapStick, and some eyeliner for

never got acne. Just facial "beauty" in America just... Never ceases to

comments.text:
Personally I divide being "attracted to someone into two different 
categories: beauty and sexiness. 
For me, these things have very different (and sometimes conflicting) 
qualifiers.

Let's start with beauty. For me, my ideal girl has brown hair, freckles, is 
somewhat short (I find it weird if a girl is taller than me, and I'm 
average-shortish), has a round-ish head (as opposed to a potato or vertical 
oval head), and is built somewhat small in general.

With sexiness, I find bigger girls attractive. I don't really care about 
boobs or anything, I just find that fat girls get me turned on. I like 
girls that have a bigger belly, especially if it jiggles when she walks.
I also find it attractive when girls eat a lot, especially if they eat 
something besides a salad or something.

DONT JUDGE ME ITS WHO I AM!
Everyone is just born with certain preferences.﻿

comments.text:
in evolutionary psychology, male attraction to women is thought to be based 
on the ability of a girl to provide good healthy offspring (youthful 
appearances are most valued here), while female attraction to men is based 
more on the ability of the man to be a good provider for the offspring (in 
early human history this would have resulted from the man being a good 
hunter which requires strength, but in modern times it is more based on the 
earning power of the man). It really comes down to the relative cost of 
sexual reproduction for each sex, sperm are cheap pregnancy is not, so (in 
the scenario that no laws prevent it) men are able to mate with many women 
but a woman can only mate with so many men before she becomes pregnant. 
These behaviors are reversed with the advent of anti-polygamy laws and 
modern contraceptives, but their inherent influence still remains prevalent 
in society in what each sex finds desirable.﻿

comments.text:
It is so wierd how our brains are warped to these things. I mean, as I look 
around I consciously know that some people don't wear makeup and aren't in 
perfect shape, they are in the same boat as me. But then in the morning I 
am still extremely hesitant to not put on face makeup to hide any pimples 
or whatever. It is insane how things can affect us even if we KNOW things 
at the surface. I don't think a lot of people understand that. They tell 
people, everyone is going thru the same thing. You have nothing to be 
insecure about! but everyone has thier own insecurities and its ok. I mean, 
it would be better not too, but still. And I appreciate that hank said 
something about it being ok to express yourself with makeup and things. 
Because a lot of people who are trying to be inspiring are undermining the 
fact that some people use makeup as an art or hobby or even passion. And 
thats awesome. What isnt awesome is doing it because you feel you have to 
or to impress someone who wouldnt accept you if you didnt have it on.﻿

comments.author: Waltham1892

comments.text:
Dude.  Thank you for saying this.  I try to tell all my girlfriends (like, 
my friends who are girls), especially my *girlfriend* girlfriend, that each 
of them have worth and beauty that is deeper than what everyone sees.  I 
mean, it's just sad that our culture insists that women are supposed to 
look a certain way--and even, to a lesser degree, that men are also 
supposed to look some way or another--and worse, that the value of that 
person (interpreted almost like a commodity more than an individual) is 
determined, at least in part, by how well this criteria is met.  The worth 
of an individual is something that they have inside them, because of *who* 
they are, not what.  People are just that--people.  They aren't 
commodities, items to be inspected and given a rating, and I'm always happy 
when I find someone else who opposes this philosophy.﻿

comments.text:
So I watched this video and I noticed it only looked at this issue from one 
side and that is that women “have to” wear makeup and it didn't at all 
explore the possibility that women “get” to wear makeup. Let’s take for 
example 2 people who are in most other ways similar but one is male and the 
other is female. One of the noteworthy ways these two are similar, however 
unfortunate, is that they both by the standards of our society are fairly 
ugly. The female in this case has an incredibly wide array of options to 
deal with this that are absent for the male in the form of cosmetics. In 
this light one could argue the counter point that it is unfair that men 
“can't” wear makeup. One thing that makes this complaint by women sound so 
hallow to me is that they already have monumental advantage in the 
particulars of the social circumstance that this video is referring to and 
that is attracting the attention of a potential mate of the opposite sex. 
Just to be clear I would totally be willing to trade a little extra time 
getting ready each day for the all of the privileges women have in this 
social situation. What privileges do I mean you ask? Most notably is the 
ability to enters a social setting, sit down and wait for someone to 
 approach taking all the risk of rejection onto them self and very likely 
making offerings of sustenance and entertainment for the opportunity to win 
you over. Yes I would make that swap in a heartbeat. One last thing on the 
subject of girls basing self worth on being attractive to boys and 
well.....a similar phenomenon exists for us also over here on the male side 
also, especially at younger ages such as during high school, our self worth 
may be measured in large part by our successes with the ladies.﻿

comments.text:
Not all boys, like this one making this comment, are attracted to females. 
That will probably change, as bodies continue to go through pub, not the 
bar, I mean growth. Still in the middle of it. I have seen 7th graders who 
love each other then, and 10th graders starting to be attracted to each 
other. Also do not find it weird that say a 9th grader is attracted to an 
8th grader, think about it, your mom and dad might be a couple years apart. 
Couldn't 13 year olds do the same with a 14 year old? Enough about that, 
but parents should probably not be using the slogan just don't have sex, 
that is probably not enough, especially to 17 year olds, who have 
transportation, a very independent mind and a body just out of pub that 
that is ready to reproduce, or at least preform the actions to do simulate 
it without actually making a child. Instead, try saying that 1/4 of birth 
control methods other than actually doing something like clamping the tubes 
from the ovaries to the womb, therefore making it impossible to make a 
baby, they fail, which may release not only sperm cells, but also STD. 
Perhaps show a picture of someone with syphilis. That would be pretty 
creepy, maybe list the symptoms. Romantic behavior is not always bad, as 
long as the relationship, is not one of domination or with either one 
feeling bad about it, then again, some may be embarrassed to have one, but 
I mean bad about being in a relationship because of the other party. It is 
fine to be open, and while I haven'y felt what is feels like, the teachers 
almost certainly have, I heard it is like your legs are almost literally 
made of jello, or that you feel compelled to draw the face of the crush all 
day, and can't concentrate on anything else, which may be a problem in 
school, so maybe the school should try to work with that, adding it to any 
individual programs, like my school board has something called Individual 
Programming plan for someone with anything that could make a problem in 
education, and because of autism, I had a goal of raising my hand a certain 
number of times per week, but I really didn't care about that part because 
when it was in effect, I did not read my IPP, it was pretty much only 
relevant to the teachers and two parents, my own, involved. They didn't 
flat out tell me: Ok, raise your hand X times per week or something else 
will happen. They just monitored and tried making questions they knew I was 
eager to answer. Teenage bodies are designed to attract those of the 
opposite sex, just like other animals. Male peacock feather displays, 
believe it or not, try to attract female peacocks to mate. Humans have 
other things, like lips and hair, styled to make others want to be with 
them. Same with breasts and pecs for men, I have friends who are growing 
mustaches, and a primary purpose of them is to attract. You know the 
Myth-busters, the TV show? They put Kari in various sized things I forget, 
D size, C size, I don't know what they are referring to, but it was on the 
episode on laws of attraction. She made more money, pretending to be a 
barrister in the D size than the c size because they apparently made her 
more attractive. Some things humans do exclusively for the purpose of 
attracting one another. Humans celebrate Valentines day the the purpose of 
celebrating love, and people dedicate their lives to studying it. ﻿

are very random, they're not even 50% or 30% random, and that's why you 
can't do much to change yourself.

There are evolutionary traits people are atracted to, symetrical face, long 
legs, wide hips, plump breasts, and as much as you like to think that it's 
mostly random and so you have no say and shoulnd't worry is wrong.

Now you don't get me wrong, I don't think people should worry too much 
about their appearance, specially seeing that make up can change your 
appearance, but the core evolutionary factors I described can't.

But, let's not make this guy's mistake. Yes, we shouldn't worry too much, 
but no, factors of attraction are most certrainly not mostly random, 
altough I'm well aware they change from culture to culture.

Bottom line, take his lesson and understand that you shouldn't let your 
self worth be determined by external factors.

But, please be aware of his mistake, which is the self acceptance cliche 
that everyone likes, and is the reason this video was so well recieved:

You sholdn't feel bad about yourself, not because beauty standards are 
random and therefore we're all beautiful in our own way, but instead facing 
the reality of your situation, and understanding that you shouldn't put 
your self worth entirely on external factors.﻿
comments.author: Francisco Pinto

comments.text:

attraction in men for a certain body shape is up for debate. here

contribute by participating in the survey..... and I don't think the dude 
missed the point of Hank's vid so much, actually.

Thank you sooooo Much Hank!!!!! I just got hurt pretty bad last night by my

applies to me so well.

comments.author: Schnappi fckingcrocodile

comments.text:
+Schnappi fckingcrocodile   I'm just sayin' that saying' women aren't 
"forced" to wear makeup is a lot like the school bully saying he's not 
"forcing" you to lick the toilet--he's just going to punch you if you 
don't.  Sure, it's technically still a choice, but if there are negative 
(and, depending on your location and career path, sometimes severe) 
consequences being imposed on a particular choice, it's not exactly a free 
choice.
I mean, most of us would love to not care what society thinks and go to 
work in our pyjamas with no makeup, but a lot of us need to care if we want 
to get a promotion, and I think that's important to take into account when 
you're talking about why women wear makeup, and if they should.
comments.author: KyteGlory

comments.text:
+KyteGlory Yeah, sure I see that, but that doesn't mean you have absolutely 
no choice, your life isn't worthless without makeup. Then again I don't 
really like society and people in general so it might be just me who 
doesn't really care.
comments.author: Schnappi fckingcrocodile

comments.text:
+Schnappi fckingcrocodile That depends on your understanding of coercion. 
Studies show that women who don't wear makeup are less likely to be hired. 
They're less likely to receive assistance from others if they need help or 
make a mistake. They're less likely to be perceived as responsible, less 
likely to be perceived as intelligent, and less likely to be perceived as 
friendly. Women who wear makeup do better--objectively--in their careers 
and social lives because people perceive them and treat them better. So 
yeah, there is kind of an ultimatum to wearing makeup.
Not to mention, there are definitely workplaces (especially administrative 
careers--trust me, you won't find a female CEO that doesn't wear makeup) 
that require women to wear makeup. Shit, I've even worked in offices where 
women were not only required to wear makeup, but required to be skilled in 
applying it, and they would be pulled aside and talked to if their makeup 
wasn't blended well enough.
comments.author: KyteGlory

comments.text: Society sucks.
comments.author: LuLu Glitter Jr.

comments.text:
Sure "not forced". Technically true. But we do live in a society that shuns 
women who don't. I know you may think this isn't true because most people 
would not knowingly do so. But a woman who doesn't wear any makeup usually 
will have trouble getting work, getting friends, and dates. Like it or not 
it's the truth. There are exceptions. I used to be one. But many women 
hated me for it because "you don't have to wear make-up!!" I had great skin 
and could get away with little to none. But no more! Truthfully it's 
subconscious. Most of us don't realize how we size people up and assume a 
woman without makeup is "unkempt" and doesn't "take care of herself". We 
may not even know why.

comments.text:
My earliest experience of being judged on my looks, was at about 6 or 7 
years old when I asked my mother if I could cut my hair short and she said 
I could but I wasn't to come crying to her if boys didn't like me. I think 
what parents say to children at a young age is so important as it can 
affect them for the rest of their lives. The amount of times as a very 
young child 3 maybe 4 years old I heard my mother say something along the 
lines of " my thighs are soooo huge, my stomach is so big or my waist isn't 
small enough" affect me so much that at 9 years old I developed an eating 
disorder, to conform to my mothers idea of beauty or the perfect body. If 
there are any parents reading this, please, I beg of you to not say these 
things in ground of your children, it can affect them for the rest of their 
lives.﻿
comments.author: Megan Sykes

comments.text:
That's a lot to go through at nine. I can imagine eating disorders are a 
lot to got through at any age. I remember a time when I was like 12 and I 
noticed that I was way taller then my other female friends. The all wanted 
to be 5 foot 8 inches like I am but I wanted to be 5 foot 3 inches like 
them. I feel that woman and girls always compare themselves to standards of 
beauty that are unrealistic. And when these standards aren't achieved we 
think bad of are selves. And that is so sad that most girls by the age of 
ten already have body insecurities.
comments.author: harmony smith

comments.text:
There are a million online and magazine articles about how women can be 
more appealing to men- 'what guys look for in a girl', 'fashion trends men 
hate', 'dumb things women do to drive men away', 'beauty trends men hate', 
'what men think about your shoes' (no shit, that one is real). Women's 
magazines are all about how to make men want you, love you, commit to you, 
stay with you, approve of you. Yet, rarely is the same focus made of men- 
there will be no articles telling you what clothes to stop wearing for our 
benefit, which personality traits to cultivate or conceal as it pleases us, 
how to get us to commit, our opinions on our shoes. When men's magazines 
mention relationships, it's in the form of articles on how to get women 
into bed, or what to say (what lies to tell) to avoid an argument, how shop 
for lingerie for your girlfriend, how to tell when it's time to dump 
someone, "Is she high maintanence?" quizzes. You won't be told what's wrong 
with you that's driving women away. Media assumes that women live for men, 
and men live for themselves.﻿
comments.author: moonlily1

comments.text:
Hank, before I say anything else, I want to say that I'm not stalking your 
old videos just to randomly comment on it...in fact, I this is the video I 
watch every night before I go to bed which is what I wanted to talk to you 
about. I'm going to be honest with you, I like every other teenage girl has 
at one point been sucked into the game of makeup and hair and expensive 
clothing in order to impress boys. I watched this video my freshman year of 
high school which was my lowest year... I valued my life on what others 
said about me and try to conform myself into someone else in order to 
please others. And I started watching this video because it seemed like you 
were simply informing about what other cultures do, when the video changed 
my life. (I know, the sappiest thing you've ever read, right?) well, it's 
true. I had never thought about what my life would be like if I stopped 
caring about others opinion of me was and instead cared on what I valued 
myself. I have grown out of the makeup and expensive clothes phase, but I 
still watch this video every night to remind myself of why. I just simply 
wanted to reach out and tell you, thanks. You may read this, you may not 
and that's fine. I'm simply a nerdfighter who is proud to say that your 
wisdom and humor has brought joy to my life.

Congrats on meeting the president, exciting! And I'll see you here tomorrow 
night as usual. 
DFTBA 
﻿
comments.author: Jillian Howell
